text: welcome mr. Matt Landsman before we
start properly just tell us a bit about
you how would you describe your own
politics would you say you were a
revolutionary for instance well no I
don't know a revolution now I want to
transform society into a completely
different sort of society socialists
would do absolutely you know I want to
see a society that treats people as you
know that that has that whose
government's design policies that are
for the benefit of people not for profit
and momentum has a series of core
beliefs as it where it's an ideological
organized if you sign up to momentum and
you sign up to these beliefs I'm not
using ideological inner in a hostile
sense but for instance you say that you
must redistribute wealth and power from
the many from the few to the many that
is certainly true but I think most of
the people who've joined the Labour
Party actually come in with very little
ideological baggage you know they don't
remember the Soviet Union they don't
remember the debates that I was involved
in in the nineteen and 80s you know when
I when I helped to organize Tony
Bennett's campaign one of the problems
about the 1970s and the 80s from the
point of view of the left is the left
hated each other and they hated other
Labour Party members more sometimes than
they seem to hate the Tories it was a
lot of internal friction is that still a
problem I I think there was internal
strife and I think we've you know I've
learnt the lessons that internal strife
doesn't help the labour party I think we
saw that in in the starting point of the
general election campaign which followed
two years of too much strife in the
party after jeremy corbyn's first
victory but I think we've put that
behind us now in this conference in
which the party was really united you
know around this program well not the
one in Manchester the one in Brighton
last week you know which which was a
really really healthy and I think we're
now a United Party and I I don't think
that they you know I don't think that
we've written that we can return to that
time you know we in the general election
campaign we went out in campaign for MP
for candidates right across the
political spectrum the Labour Party and
now you have organizers up and down the
country and constituencies up and down
the country trying right at this moment
to topple lots of Tory MPs who are here
in Manchester what's your message to
them well they've eaten they need to
prepare because we're in their
constituencies now we're all we're
training our kin
to persuade people on the doorstep we're
mobilizing thousands of people every
weekend to go to Tory marginals and
unseat Tory MPs let's return to the
politics of it you talk about a
redistribution of wealth and we both
know that wealth in this country is
concentrated in property and pensions
and so forth and yet so far the Labour
Party is not prepared to talk about
wealth tax it's talk about income tax
rises but doesn't the Labour Party need
to address the idea of a wealth tax well
I I think you know we we're at a worse
an early stage in the development of the
detail of the policy that was presented
in the manifest in the country that you
know it's the first time in my life that
I've been knocking on doors and found
voters who've already read a hurtful in
Party manifesto would know what's in it
so it inspired lots of enthusiasm we've
got to put more detail in it over the
next between now and the election
however long that takes the great
confrontation some would say in the
modern world is between us who were
politics on the one hand social
democracy on the one hand and the big
big corporations who are reshaping life
everywhere
very often avoiding paying taxes and so
forth and to deal with that you need the
biggest organizations you can and it's
been the EU who has taken on Google not
the British government well I think the
thing about modern capitalism is that
global corporations are now so global so
international that they can ride
roughshod over not only nation-states
but in but even the EU and that is what
we are so that being so why did you
organize at Brighton to stop the Labour
Party debating brexit what happened at
Brighton was we had lots of debate about
brexit we knew we were going to have the
the the the there was a vote on the NSE
statement which was overwhelmingly
carried there there were speeches by
kiss Dharma and Emily Thornbury but in
outside the conference chamber there was
lots of debate on the fringes including
at many fringe meetings that we we
organize wasn't just an attempt to avoid
embarrassing Jeremy Caldwell very not
brexit is not the only thing that is
important you know there were other
policies that we wanted to promote we
wanted a discussion about the NHS which
is in crisis about housing you know
which which is the the the the lack of
affordable housing is now affecting the
families of all you know right across
the special spectrum about railways
about social carefully elderly so those
were the subjects that we positively
promoted and you know there are lots of
things that are important to discuss one
thing that's important to discuss you
come from a devout and traditional
Jewish family yourself there's been a
lot of conversation about anti-semitism
on the left and in the Labor Party and
the leader of Brighton Council who's a
Labour man I said he doesn't want the
Labour Party back in Brighton until it
sorted out his anti-semitism problem as
a Jew yourself how do you feel about
that the mood on parts of the of the
left about Israel and about Jewishness
well look first of all there is a
popular anti-semitism is a problem
throughout society it would be extremely
surprising if it wasn't also present in
the labour party alongside
other forms of discrimination which is
why I'm so pleased that the National
Executive Labor Party
put a statement which made very clear
our absolute opposition to all forms of
discrimination anti-semitism if some
affirm it and so on and you know it's
incredibly important to me as a Jew you
know my Jewish identity is important to
me and actually my reading as a child
about the oppression and victimization
of Jews through the centuries from the
Roman Empire to the 27 culminating in
their in the Holocaust it's what define
my politics so I'm very clearly against
any form of anti-semitism so when you
hear people like Ken Loach all Paul
McCloskey saying there's not really any
anti-semitism problem the Labour Party
I've never heard an anti-semitic comment
do you think there's a danger or a
slight blindness on that subject by some
people they think we're on the Left we
can't possibly be discriminatory we
can't possibly be anti-semitic and they
don't really think about it well I think
it is the case that you know you have to
be a Jew to actually experience
anti-semitism I have actually
experienced anti-semitism my children
who are only half Jewish or not how
logically Jewish have experienced
anti-semitism I know that there is a
problem with anti-semitism and it has to
be know a little bit it's a little bit
strange having you here in the middle of
the Tory Party conference oh I can't
resist the last question a message for
the Prime Minister will be on that sofa
shortly
well IIIi would ask her you know with we
you've been talking about abuse in
activate which is the name of the of
that imitation momentum in the Tory
party one of their activists talked
about gassing chaffs
in the context of of the appalling
disaster at Grenville tower I'd like to
know what she has to say to those
activists
